intro: Acer saccharum var. floridanum, commonly known as the Florida sugar maple, is a variant of the sugar maple native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves that turn vibrant yellow in the fall. The tree typically grows to a height of 20-40 feet and has a slender, upright form. Its bark is smooth and gray, with a slight furrowed texture as it matures. This variety is well adapted to moist, acidic soils and is often found in the understory of hardwood forests.
